(1 comment)
Needs more details here.  When we're interpreting as bytes, what's the potential problem?
@gunnar mentioned that intel raised the security issue but I don't have any information about it.

I'm not sure how you came to this conclusion.  From the specification:

"A client POST to this URI shall contain the Content-Type HTTP header with the value multipart/
form-data , with the body formatted as defined by this specification. For more information about
multipart/form-data HTTP requests, see RFC7578."

> There are all content types bmcweb supports. There is no multipart in the list so you are saying we should add multipart in the list and support it?
> 
> constexpr std::array<ContentTypePair, 5> contentTypes{{
>     {"application/cbor", ContentType::CBOR},
>     {"application/json", ContentType::JSON},
>     {"application/octet-stream", ContentType::OctetStream},
>     {"text/html", ContentType::HTML},
>     {"text/event-stream", ContentType::EventStream},
> }};
> 

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/994fd86a3f6649a820f66313765e85e762ad105a/include/login_routes.hpp#L121

Matches against multipart, but you're right, it doesn't use the new generic functions, which we could fix.

> 
> I just checked what IBM GUI requests for and it is octet-stream.
> 
> [DEBUG "update_service.hpp":627] handleUpdateServicePost: content: application/octet-stream

This is not an appropriate way to match the specification.  Now, the background you're missing is that we actually support BOTH http multipart and OctetStream.  Multipart is defined by the standard, the other is only used by the gui.  Your patch breaks the multipart one.
ok, I will add it. Thanks!
Done

The "isContentTypeAllowed" is generally read against the accepts header, not the content-type header.  The fact that this code works is somewhat of an accident, because a single content-type header is the same as a single accepts header, but this code will allow multiple accepts headers, which is incorrect.
There are tests returned to check the content type.

This file has all positive and negative tests then I am not sure why you are saying it. Do I have to fix this code.

/include/http_utility_test.cpp

As a concrete example, if I call this method with

Content-Type: application/json application/octet-stream

It will succeed, even though the request was invalid.  Content-type can only have one thing.

I get that the naming of this function is non-ideal, but it's still incorrect to be using it.  For Content-Type, you can do direct string matching, like we do in parseJsonRequest.
It is also used for other than "Accept" here:  https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/include/forward_unauthorized.hpp#LL21C29-L21C29
ok, I will fix it.
Done
Shouldn't this be an ERROR instead of DEBUG?
No not error, it is a bad result
We don't want to spit error for user mistake. someone can exploit it.
This is the test that's incorrect if you pass in a Content-Type header instead of an Accepts header.
Removed these tests for now.

In the flow, can you please make this control the flow of the branches on line 703 and 701?  If the Content-Type is not form-data, we should not be running it through the form-data parser.

As written, the flow still tries to part octet-stream as form data.

Please check my latest code and see if that is ok. I was able to send data of type multipart/form-data like this but it expect some attributes.

filename=$image_file
filetype='multipart/form-data'
token=$TOKEN
url="https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/UpdateService/update"

curl -k -H "X-Auth-Token: $TOKEN" \
  --form "file=@$filename;type=$filetype" \
  "$url"
I found the way to test multipart/form-data. Added the result in the Tested section of the commit.
Thank you.
Removed the old code for handling multi-part accepts headers.

How does this play with https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/64072 ?
When insecure-ignore-content-type is enabled, should we ignore this check?
Good catch. Should we wait to see if anyone complains about it?
